DOC.HEAD: New Government To Lift Martial Law, Seeks Vote Of Confidence
Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with anti-corruption campaign; Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Under martial ...'
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Mudar Badran told the new Parliament today his government will lift martial law, which for 22 years has banned large public meetings and allowed authorities to restrict freedom of speech. Badran, seeking a vote of confidence from the newly elected legislature, added that until martial law is formally revoked most of its provisions will be ``frozen'' effective immediately. He also vowed his administration will crack down on corruption by public officials and criticized former governments for deficit spending that swelled Jordan's $8.3 billion foreign debt. Under martial law, which King Hussein imposed after the 1967 Arab-Israeli war, authorities also can close newspapers at any time, effectively inhibiting free criticism of officials. It also provides for special courts. Most candidates in last month's general elections called for the lifting of martial law and many demanded the legalization of political parties, which currently are banned. Badran said a constitutional court will be formed to secure citizens' rights as stipulated by the constitution. He lifted legal immunity from government officials and said he would put forward legislation requiring an officeholder to present ``a comprehensive and documented report of all his possessions.'' The announcement of such a financial disclosure requirement was aimed at ensuring the integrity of public officials. The government of Prime Minister Zeid Rifai, which resigned earlier this year after bloody rioting, was widely accused of corruption. The largest bloc in the new lower house is made up of Islamic fundamentalists or their sympathizers. ``I announce in this Parliament that martial law is now considered frozen ... until such laws are constitutionally abolished in the near future,'' Badran told the lower house of Parliament. It was the latest in a series of moves towards democracy and liberalization announced by the king and by Badran's government, which was formed Dec. 6. The lower house has to approve all laws and has the power to throw out prime ministers and their Cabinets. Still, King Hussein can block any laws in the royally appointed Senate or through a veto, and he has frequently used the power to dissolve Parliament and rule by decree. Last month, Hussein promised a ``gradual reduction'' in the activities of the martial law courts and said their responsibilities would be transfered to civil courts. On Dec. 10, Badran announced his government would return confiscated passports and promised further amnesties for political prisoners, after 48 were released by the previous government. He told Parliament then that he ordered authorities to give all Jordanian citizens freedom of movement and the right to work, in accordance with the king's instructions. Badran said he did not know how many passports had been confiscated, but security sources said the number was more than 8,700. Many of those whose passports were confiscated had said security officials intervened to bar them from jobs. The November elections were the first nationwide poll since 1967 when Israel captured the West Bank from Jordan. Hussein last year renounced Jordan's claim to the West Bank in favor of the Palestine Liberation Organization. The fundamentalist Moslem Brotherhood Movement captured the most seats in the lower house of Parliament _ 25 out of a total of 80 _ but Badran earlier this month formed a government without the movement that advocates stricter Islamic laws. By law, the new 23-member Cabinet has to appear before lower house for a vote of confidence within 30 days. If approved by a simple majority of 41 votes, the government will be installed. If not, King Hussein will have to name a new prime minister.
